Message.Title: Oracle Should Stand the Test of Time...and Is A Good Long Term Bet
Message.Msg: Trust me, having been in a number of competitor companies, I've always hated Oracle for many reasons. However, I've always respected and admired Oracle for its business success. No matter what one might say, Oracle is an enterprise ecosystem, powering many companies. Core to this ecosystem is its database. Sorry, I don't but that it's just a commodity. PL-SQL on Oracle databases underpins lots of cloud computing applications, never mind in house systems. Oracle applications and other applications optimally work with Oracle databases. I know for a fact that some prominent cloud companies build their core technology stacks on mostly Oracle systems. Finally, if I learned anything the hard way, it's that Oracle tends to adjust & adapt to change at the right time. I remember working for a database vendor in the mid 90s when the internet boom started. We touted our ability to handle more connections simultaneously than Oracle. However, Oracle partnered with middleware companies to pool connections for internet apps...something we didn't do initially. Hence, Oracle got the early jump and branded itself as "powering the internet". Likewise, I think it is only a matter of time before Oracle starts to take market share in cloud computing apps. Again, they have nearly all the components to build out SaaS stacks cheaply. Moreover, as to financials, look at their valuation, cash flow, and balance sheets...as compared to, for example, SalesForce. My bet is that Oracle will prove to be a winner over the long haul. This looks to be a decent entry point. Larry Ellison is still vigorous and should continue to guide the company for a long time to come. I'm definitely looking to start a long position.

Topic.Title: Oracle Should Stand the Test of Time...and Is A Good Long Term Bet

Message.Msg: You probably are right about more of a pullback here. Moreover, the market seems to be favoring potential growth like CRM, AMZN, and LNKD, whilst quick to punish companies like Apple and Oracle that actually make decent profits. At a current PE of 14, Oracle seems a fair value right now, although like you inferred, it could be gotten for cheaper. But in my book, I'd rather take Oracle now and bet on good odds of decent returns...as opposed to being a bag holder in the aforementioned companies when the market inevitably corrects. My philosophy is that it is more important to avoid a serious loss than to win a big one. I don't chase growth, other than with play money. My serious money goes into companies like Oracle, Apple, IBM, MSFT, and so.

Assemblyman Joe Cryan, of Union, graphically spelled out his kinky proclivities in more than 150 e-mails that he sent to a lobbyist — and then fought to keep them hidden after he stunned the state political world by having her busted for stalking in 2006. Cryan urged prosecutors for years to keep the courts from releasing the e-mails’ sexually charged content, while Golding pushed to get them out, first referring to them in court papers in 2009. With the case still playing out in court, the secret correspondence — racy enough to make any “Fifty Shades of Grey’’ fan blush — landed on the driveway of a Post reporter. “What do you want to be spanked with?” the lascivious lawmaker asked Golding in an inappropriate workday exchange that spanned 14 hours on June 28, 2004. “What will you wear to beg for it?” “Available for a bj this morning?” Cryan lustfully queried. “I’m really hard and #$%$.” The e-mails were written when the pol presumably would have been at one of his government jobs — either his $49,000-a-year Assembly gig or his $111,000-a-year post as Union County undersheriff.
